evidence.text: Fundicao Tupy S.A. v. United States, 841 F.2d 1101, 1103 (Fed. Cir. 1988) (“[A] preliminary injunction is . . . ‘ipso facto dissolved by a dismissal of the complaint.’” (quoting 7 J. KBC Bank NV, 590 F.3d 1091, 1094 (9th Cir. 2010) (quoting Fundicao Tupy S.A., 841 F.2d at 1103).

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff

evidence.text: IT IS ORDERED that: 1. Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction (Dkt. 17) is GRANTED. 2. The Court hereby restrains and enjoins the State of Idaho, including all of its officers, employees, and agents, from enforcing Idaho Code § 18-622(2)-(3) as applied to medical care required by the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd.

IT IS ORDERED that: 1. Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction (Dkt. 17) is GRANTED. 2. The Court hereby restrains and enjoins the State of Idaho, including all of its officers, employees, and agents, from enforcing Idaho Code § 18-622(2)-(3) as applied to medical care required by the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd.
Settlement is court-enforced (see 'Whether_the_Settlement_is_Court-enforced_or_Not') so no disputes over enforcement exist

The United States of America filed this case against the State of Idaho on August 2, 2022, challenging Idaho Code § 18-622(2), which makes it a felony for anyone to perform or attempt to perform or assist with an abortion.

extracted.value: The United States alleges Idaho Code § 18-622 criminalizes abortions necessary to save a pregnant woman's life, violating EMTALA

evidence.text: Signed by Judge B Lynn Winmill.
This preliminary injunction is effective immediately and shall remain in full force and effect through the date on which judgment is entered in this case.
